title: Part 5
content:
Part 5

I GENERALLY DIDN'T have preferences.

This applied not only to food but also to the curriculum.

It respected traditional cultures such as music related to piano and violin, calligraphy, and tea ceremony.

It just consisted of days where we faced the tasks at hand, but among them, there was one thing I felt particularly reluctant about.

It was a curriculum introduced the year we turned six, conducted once or twice a month for half a day. It was a class called 'Travel' where we used a virtual console.

The children stood up, and all of us put on large goggles.

The view went completely dark. Soon, the screen lit up displaying the program, and then it began.

"Until now, we've learned about places like New York and Hawaii in America, but from now on, the curriculum will focus on Japan, starting with basic public transportation."

The fundamental premise of the class: This world is not just the White Room.

This time was still considered a part of our education, and we were told early on that we couldn't leave here until we became adults.

The virtual console recreated the scenery with such high quality, indistinguishable from reality, in 360 degrees, and the sound combined with the visuals produced a sense of immersion. It even replicated people passing by, such as businessmen in suits, an old man with a cane, and an old woman trying to get into a taxi, showing the cityscape.

Of course, there were also children, but unlike the outside world, there was no playing or enjoyment,

just inorganic, mechanical movements.

We learned history and the world's structure in this place.

Through this activity, when the time came when I'd eventually step into the outside world, I would be able to adapt to things smoothly without having any issues.

I understand it's necessary, but I think there's a problem with this method of learning.

One reason for my reluctance was the uncomfortable feeling that lingered.

This was commonly referred to as '3D sickness.'

The balance recognized by the vision and the vestibular system was off, and the brain could mistakenly think it was seeing hallucinations.

There was no way to stop the nausea through just personal effort; the only method was to let the brain learn over time.

It wasn't so severe that it was impossible to continue, but that was the reason I couldn't like it.

Of course, this virtual console wasn't only used as a device to visually recognize the outside world.

It was also utilized as a tool to train observation and insight.

In various places, we were required to point out what was unnatural in the unfolding stories.

If the spots we pointed to were wrong or if we couldn't find those spots at all, the instructors would mercilessly correct you.

The methods of correction varied, but they were mainly methods that caused pain.

That was why we observe desperately, not sparing even a blink.

The sense of danger sharpened our senses so much that we started to see things we couldn't see before.

"Then next—"

As I was walking through Tokyo on the virtual console, suddenly the screen was enveloped in darkness.

The instructors' voices that I had been listening to also stopped, and silence enveloped us.

"Everyone, remove your goggles."

The voice came not through the microphone, but from within the room, and we all followed the instructions at once.

"There's an equipment malfunction. We'll end today's virtual console session here. There are still less than thirty minutes until the next curriculum, so please wait here."

With those instructions, they collected everyone's goggles.

"Wait here…"

Most of the children remained standing. It seemed they intended to kill time by just standing there.

Eventually, it turned out that the equipment issue couldn't be resolved quickly enough, so the instructors decided to move on to a different curriculum.

The children were, of course, quickly lined up and switched their focus to the next task.

"From now on, I will call out names one by one. Those called will get moving and follow the instructor."

With those instructions, the first three names were called.

Eventually, I was the last to be called. When I was following the instructor, he walked slowly and invited me into a private room.

There were no other children. It was just a one-on-one with the instructor.

In the center of the room, there was only a small table and two pipe chairs.

"Sit down quickly."

I wasn't stopping, but the instructor commanded me to sit down immediately, hitting the table.

When I sat in front of the instructor, five cards were laid out in his hand.

Each had a different symbol drawn on it.

Starting from the left, there was a circle, square, cross, star, and wave—five symbols.

"I will demonstrate what I want you to do. Observe carefully."

The instructor, facing me, turned all the cards face down.

Since the backs of the five cards had the same pattern, it was impossible to tell which card had which symbol when shuffled like this.

Looks like I'm supposed to identify a specific card among them and reveal it to him.

That was what I thought, but—

The five cards were rearranged.

"There will only be ten seconds per turn."

"…Square."

As he spoke, the instructor flipped the card on the far left.

It was a star.

He got it wrong, but the instructor continued, flipping the cards and stating the symbols.

"Circle, star, cross, wave—"

From the second to the fifth card, the sequence was wave, square, cross, circle.

Only the fourth card, the cross, was correct. Thus, my accuracy rate was 20%.

"This is one cycle, and we will repeat this ten times. Watch carefully."

This task, to correctly guess five times, was repeated ten times. It was a total of fifty guesses.

He continued the same task monotonously.

The final accuracy rate was 30% with fifteen correct answers out of fifty attempts.

"Now, it's your turn, Kiyotaka."

"Okay."

I stood up and took the seat, switching places with the instructor who had previously been answering the activity.

What's the purpose of this practice?

It probably isn't for developing psychic abilities.

To train intuition?

No, that seems too straightforward, too realistic.

The instructor shuffled the five cards.

He always used an overhand shuffle to mix the cards each time.

Is this just a habit, or something intentional?

It was impossible to determine, and it was easy to dismiss it as meaningless information.

If there is a meaning, I wonder what it could be.

The material of the desk seemed to suggest that it would be smooth and easy to perform a wash shuffle while the cards were on the table.

Was there a reason he was deliberately using an overhand shuffle?

Another thing that caught my attention was that the instructor didn't always arrange the cards from the same position.

Sometimes, he started from the left end, other times from the middle, then the right end, and then the left again.

Having watched him ten times, I couldn't discern any pattern.

I couldn't dismiss this as mere habit.

Even upon close inspection, I couldn't feel any difference from the cards' backs.

It seemed unlikely that either the instructor or I could distinguish them.

However, there was a significant difference between the instructor and me.

It was whether one could touch the cards or not.

Only the instructor handled the cards, whether shuffling, dealing, or flipping them.

If he didn't want me to sense it… could it be…?

It must've been because the instructor could see the cards, which supposedly he shouldn't have been able to.

However, even if he could see them, it didn't change the fact that I couldn't.

I wasn't forbidden from reaching out and touching the cards, but was that the proper move?

By this point, it had become clear that this wasn't merely an activity to increase intuition.

Then, a possible rule is… 

Five cards were laid out, and a ten-second count began.

To increase the accuracy by even 1%, the first symbol I'd say was decided.

"Star—"

As I answered, the instructor, with an unchanged expression, flipped the card on the far left.

The 'star' revealed itself.

It was still just one out of five.

"Wave, square, cross, circle."

From the second to the fifth card, the instructor flipped them as I called out the symbols.

The marks I spoke were turned over as the correct answers.

"There are still nine more rounds."

"Yes."

With these five correct answers, I became confident in one rule.

Then, the rest was easy.

From there, I correctly guessed all forty-five cards in the remaining nine rounds.

"You're 100% accurate…"

As the instructor collected the fiftieth card, he looked at me.

Emotions that weren't previously there flickered in his eyes.

"I can't believe you already had a guess from the very first one."

The instructor, who had first demonstrated the activity, could've repeated the same thing once or at most twice just to explain the rules.

However, the instructors silently completed all ten rounds regardless of whether he was right or wrong.

It wasn't just an explanation of the rules.

He was testing memory under the guise of a practice, to see who could quickly realize this.

"Plus, perfect memory. It's hard to believe all of a sudden…"

"Didn't you remember too? You arranged the cards the same way as the first time."

"No way. What I remembered were the small, invisible scratches on the cards. I'm only memorizing the five types. The reason why the arrangement was the same as the first time was due to instructions I'm receiving through an earpiece."

"So that's why there was a camera installed in the ceiling."

"…You noticed that too?"

"I did feel strange about the way I was spoken to earlier."

When I entered the room, I was directed to focus my gaze somewhere specific.

Moreover, the urgency with which I was urged to sit down was also unnatural.

If there had been any reason to rush the curriculum, they would've hurried me before I entered the room or conducted the demonstration much faster.

"You're the first one to pass this lesson in one try… You can go back."

"If you'll excuse me."

If I considered today's lesson as a substitute for the virtual console curriculum, which I didn't really like, it was several times more enjoyable.
